newsitem.title: CHINA: China offers to send back Taiwan hijacker in May.
newsitem.headline: China offers to send back Taiwan hijacker in May.

text.p: China on Wednesday offered to repatriate in mid-May a Taiwanese who hijacked a Taiwan airliner from the island to the communist mainland in March.
The Chinese Red Cross in the southeastern province of Fujian informed its Taiwan counterpart that Liu Shan-chung would be sent back to Taiwan by sea on May 14, state radio said.
"The Taiwan authorities concerned are requested to rapidly reply to the arrangement before May 7," the radio said.
Beijing and Taipei have been rivals since the Communists won the Chinese civil war and drove the defeated Nationalists into exile on Taiwan in 1949.
Liu commandeered a Taiwan commercial jet to Xiamen on March 10, becoming the first hijacker to force a passenger plane from the island to the mainland in the 1990s rather than the other way around.
Shortly after Liu forced the jet to Xiamen, Taiwan called on Beijing to return him and offered in exchange to repatriate two mainland hijackers who had completed their prison terms.

The Straits Exchange Foundation, Taiwan's quasi-official agency in charge of dialogue with China in the absence of formal ties, said earlier this month its Beijing counterpart had offered to return Liu through the Red Cross.
Taipei is holding 16 mainlanders who hijacked a dozen planes to Taiwan in the 1990s and were convicted of air piracy.

Lee Ching-ping, deputy secretary-general of the foundation, is visiting China and has agreed with China's Ministry of Justice to step up cooperation on fighting crime and the repatriation of fugitives.
